top_comment.text:
Jajangmyeon wasn't directly taken from the Chinese, I think- it was a 
Korean take on a Chinese noodle dish called "zhajiangmian".  The Koreans, 
like the Japanese, adopted a lot of stuff from Chinese culture, not 
entirely by choice at times.﻿
top_comment.author: Ender Ragnarok

comments.text:
Look the Chinese has influenced almost all of East/South-East Asia. Heck 
most of our words for noodles are directly taken from the Chinese, Men in 
Japan, Myeon in Korea, Mie in Thailand and Laos. Also most Asian countries 
have adopted Chinese dishes, baos in Japan are nikuman,galabao in laos, 
salapao in Thailand, and so on.
comments.author: BuddhaBless328

comments.text:
+Nihilus Rose In my opinion, you are mostly correct, but I think one of the 
main reason that Chinese people in Incheon harbor started selling 
jajangmyun is that they couldn't do other things for living due to South 
Korean gov't's heavy sanction.
comments.author: 이종우

comments.text:
+swimmingmintinyoutub By the way, this noodle dish is very modern dish, 
nothing to do with historical influence. Like so many chinese take away 
around the world, its a Chisese take away food that adopted local tastes 
buds. No one can pin point the right moment but it is believed that after 
1950 war, some Korean Chinese (화교) person invented this noodle dish 
inspired by chinese food made with zhajiang (춘장, black Chinese sauce)
comments.author: swimmingmintinyoutub

comments.text:
I think it's dangerous to educate others with limited knowledge. If you're 
not sure it's best to leave it alone. I am a korean, learned the history 
throughout 12+years in classes. I know that because of the geographical 
position, Korea was subjected to many invasions from other neighbouring 
countries and obviously the culture was affected one way or another. 
However, it has never been 'conquested' or 'ruled' by a certain country, 
yes some part of korea has lost battles and had close moments to lose its 
entity but never in any time Korea lost it's country state. Only moment was 
when Japan forced korea sign treaties to assimilate into its empire in 1910 
but it all turned out to be invalid and Korea suffered a few decades of 
illegal colonial state. The rest of modern history on Russia vs US on Korea 
is quite spot on by BillboardtopMV. Koreans are one of rare nations who has 
remained as a homogeneous ethnic group for thousands years and proud of it. 
Their culture reflects that. I appreciate your interests in Korean history 
but I would more appreciate if you are more sensitive about choosing right 
words on facts. Thank you.
comments.author: swimmingmintinyoutub

짜짱면 originated from 炸醬麵. Originally a dish from 山東/산동 Province, where most 
Chinese living in Korea came from. So yes, Southern Chinese wouldn't really 
know about this. And, 炸醬麵 is more salty in China. Korean 짜짱면 on the other 
hand, is very sweet.﻿

top_comment.text:
As a Chinese, there is Jjajangmyun (炸酱面 which is in Chinese) in many 
provinces (although mostly northern) in China. Certainly, the Korean one 
tastes different. But the looking and pronunciation are very similar. 
Another example is Ramen (拉面 which is in Chinese) which is a kind of 
popular noodles in Japan. The looking and pronunciation  are also very 
similar with that in China. Of course, the Japanese one has its own styles. 
Even in different provinces in China, there are many different flavors. 
Forget about the Canadian Chinese Food!  Most of the Chinese restaurants 
overseas are originally from the Southeastern China. Their main basic food 
is rice not noodles which is eaten mostly in Northern China, let along all 
the abroad Chinese food has changed its flavor according to the local 
eating habits.       ﻿

comments.author: josh lee

comments.text:
+HelloMyNamelsBanana Actually I had both Jajangmyun and Zhe Jiang Mian. 
 It's quite different.  The Original Chinese version is mostly dry with 
little sauce which is salty and meaty.   Korean version the sauce is very 
different.  It's darker, saucier, sweeter and has onions and other veges 
fried in together with meat.  It's more like Spaghetti actually.   The Lion 
Brand Jajangmyun Sauce company that supplies like 90% of Jajang sauce is 
set up and owned by ethnic Chinese Koreans.
comments.author: Xentradi97

comments.text:
I think the first gen are retired or passed on.  It's mostly 2nd, 3rd and 
4th now I think.  Ethnic Chinese has been residing in Korea since the 13th 
century.  And the China towns in Korea were established by mostly Chinese 
from Shandong from late 1,800's.  So yes, they've been part of Korean 
history and society for some time.
comments.author: Xentradi97

comments.author: Holly Silvester

top_comment.text:
Actually, my mom cooks jajangmyeon all the time for me and she's Chinese. 
It really depends on which region chefs aim to make the food taste like 
since China is so vast and there are many cultures and a variety of tastes. 
In chinese it's called Zhajiangmian (炸酱面) and although it tastes different 
from the Korean version, there are families I've known that make 
zhajiangmian with the same consistency of Korean chinese food. In Beijing 
(where my mom is from) they use different kind of paste, and if you look it 
up, each region in china prepares the sauce and paste in so many different 
ways it's absolutely fascinating how versatile chinese food is!﻿
top_comment.author: PastelColored

top_comment.text:
Wikipedia ： Zhajiangmian (Traditional Chinese:醡醬麵, Simplified Chinese:炸酱面. 
Literally "fried sauce noodles") is a Chinese dish consisting of thick 
wheat noodles topped with a mixture of ground pork stir-fried with zhajiang 
(醡醬), which is salty fermented soybean paste. It is said[by whom?] that it 
tastes better with hand pulled noodles.

In Beijing cuisine, yellow soybean paste (黃醬) is used, while in Tianjin and 
other parts of China tianmianjiang (甜麵醬), hoisin sauce (海鮮醬), or broad 
(fava) bean sauce (荳瓣醬) may be used in place of the yellow soybean paste. 
Soy sauce can also be used instead of the soybean paste. Simplified 
Chinese:(炸酱) also means fried sauce, as the sauce itself is fried, although 
this homonym does not carry over into the Traditional Chinese term which 
describes the actual bean paste.﻿

comments.text:
+cottonpeanut Both Noodles are ingredients are different that's why.  It 
was modified to suit Korean taste and evolved as it is.  Chinese version is 
either meaty with diced pork or bit saucy with herbs and hoisin sauce.   
The taste is more to salty side.

Korean version has diced and fried onions and vege with meat and uses 
fermented paste with caramel and thereby making it salty, sweet and savory.

comments.text:
Chinese food is really interesting, there's so many different variations 
and entire food culture is different depending on the part of China, so 
Chinese immigrants from different China regions brought certain kind of 
foods and styles with them. That's how you've got Korean-Chinese food which 
is different from American-Chinese food and so on, it's really great in my 
opinion all the different takes on food you can find in one single country.

top_comment.text:
The jajjangmyeon you guys ate is really koreanize. In China we don't do it 
this way. We usually use toona sinensis, cucumber, bean-sprout, green 
bean, soybean and pork to make the "jajjang". Most importantly, instead of 
using black been paste, we use soybean paste~ So I think korean 
jajjangmyeon will taste very different from the Chinese one.﻿
top_comment.author: Estrella WJ

comments.text:
I 've had this dish in Urumqi ,XinJiang and in Beijing.  The one from 
Urumqi was made with soy beans and the one in Beijing was made with black 
beans.  Which bean is used might not be geographical but the chef's choice. 
 They were both yummy.  I don't have much experience eating this dish in 
china but a good JaJiang noodle shop will hand pull the noodles to order.

comments.text:
ThePeeBottle and? they are two different foods and they may have 
jajangmyeon now in china but as you said (which i already mentioned in 
korean) chinese migrants made it in In-chun and was first sold in 공화춘 which 
is now a museum. as simple as it sounds, jajangmyeon is derived from 
zhajiangmian but a totally different one, mixing caramel and other 
ingredients. zhajiangmian is also made with black beans but dull and salty 
as it is majorly eaten by the poor. jajangmyeon, made by chinese in korea 
for korean taste, is actually a korean food historically. just like how 
korean migrants in japan immitated bulgogi with different parts of meat 
available to create what is now known in japan as yakiniku. I learned this 
from my history book so i can tell that jajangmyeon is korean food even if 
we sell it in chinese restaurants.
comments.author: Junyeong Yang

comments.text:
+Junyeong Yang the history is that it started out as "zhajiangmian"-a salty 
black bean and minced meat sauce served with cucumber and noodles- 
originating in china. during the early 20th century, chinese immigrants 
settled in korea and introduced that noodle dish, and through alterations 
and modifications to fit the korean taste, it is now what is called 
"jajangmyeon"-a sweeter and more saucy noodle dish- in korea.
but despite the same origins, zhajiangmian (chinese) and the jajangmyeon 
(korean) taste and look kind of different.
comments.author: ThePeeBottle

captions.text: It’s time for
FOOD ADVENTURE PROGRAM FOR AWESOME PEOPLE
The Chinese Food Edition!
Sooooooooooooo
Its kind of really crappy weather outside?
Really bad
Monsoon season is not in full effect in Korea
Making everyone mopey and
unwilling to leave their houses.
And we’re not going to leave the studio with all our camera gear
So we’re going to be filming some
Inside the studio today.
Yeah, we haven’t been doing a lot of delivery videos
We haven’t even done Korean Chinese food before.
Chinese food in Korea is really really different
From the Chinese food that I grew up with.
Yes.
Ok we’re going to get to ordering now
And I’m feeling a little nervous
Because I’m really nervous whenever
I call on the phone..
Cause no one understands my accent.
I hope it doesn’t go terribly wrong
Na nan a nan a nan a
As soon as I am in a position of pressure
In regards to Korean
My mind farts out
And I can’t remember numbers or
Words and I’ll say the wrong thing
And it’s scary and horrifying.
AHHH
Ok it’s dialing
(KOREAN ORDERING)
Then I’m not going to call them back
Because that was scary! Scary!
Didn’t like it!
Get the gibblies out! Go go go!
I did it!
So our food arrived in funny detail
They gave us like..
Six chopsticks because
“The amount of food they ordered
must be for six people!”
We ordered a lot more
So we could show you
YES! That is why we did that.
We’re not going to eat all this
We did not order this food because we wanted to eat it all
This is way too much for two people to eat
YES IT IS
I could never finish this amount of food.
For science.
If you want to order for yourself
Like one dish
Or you want a special half-and-half
They have special combo versions.
I’m gonna order,
Some jjajangmyun.
NO! no wait! I gonna order some Tang Soo Yook.
Ah! I want both but I can’t eat two servings of each!
What am I gonna do?
Well don’t worry!
With Chinese food Korean delivery,
You can have the best of both worlds!
Really?! How so?!
You can order a half-and-half of each
For the price of one order!
That’s amazing!
Tell me more!
Instead of jampong or jjajjangmyun
You can get jjajjangmyeon!
You can get oojjamyeon! Bokjjamyeon!
Bokjjamyeon! Tangjjamyeon!
And even Tangbokbab!
What do those even mean?
You don’t know stupid??
Then why are even ordering Chinese food?
I just!
Here we go!
Here we go here we go again!
What’s the topic?
Men!
Simon knows the song
So here’s jjajjangmyun
This big fat little blob of noodle here
Not really well separated
Ok so, jjajangmyun is made with like a
Black bean
And I’m pretty sure it’s made with
A lot of like lard as well
So it’s not very healthy
So its not vegetarian friendly
The lard makes it better.
And you know what I feel bad
Because it’s Ramadan now
And a lot of people were saying via Twitter like
Please be considerate of us fasting during Ramadan
Sorryyyy guys. Nope. Sorry.
But it’s very delicious
Really delicious
And if you guys have ever seen Coffee Prince
There’s a scene at the beginning
In the first episode
Where she has a showdown with the dude
And Simon can show you
She takes two bowls to begin with
She mixes it all up
She like makes it into a fist and,
“Look this is my entire meal in one chopstick
but I’m not, I cant eat that all
It’s very, very sticky and filling.
Hey, jjajjangmyun eating race. GO!
What? I don’t want to be throwing.
Right over here we have the
Gochu chapchae.
So this- gochu means pepper,
OR, penis…
Normally we get just chapchae,
And it’s like the noodles
But this is pepper chapchae and this is actually just
No noodles.
I think maybe the pepper replaces the noodle
And it comes with a ggotbang? Like
Flower Boy, its like a flower bun.
And you’re supposed to like put it inside
Its got shrimp, mushrooms, onions
It actually tastes very sesame,
So there’s a very Chinese food taste to it
And this is tang-so-yuk which is like
Supposedly really popular amongst high-school students.
So if you go to a ddokboki restaurant you order this
Which is pork and breaded and deep fried
And they always serve it on the side
It’s like a sweet and sour pineapple sauce
But it’s so thick and syrupy.
Like you can see it dangling there
Ooo, that doesn’t look good.
But it tastes great.
And then we got
For service, which is for free,
Geun-Mandu, which is just like, fried, mandu (dumpling)
And you usually only get friend ones
Consistently at a Chinese food restaurant
Most Korean places do steamed.
And we also got for service little spring rolls
Which are so-so
But I haven’t had spring rolls in a long time
So I’m not gonna
Complain about it.
And of course there is the jjajjangmyun.
Before we eat all this,
How about some sexy food porn shots.
OOOOoooooOOOooOooOoo.
I don’t know how sexy this can be.
Oh, God its so good, just.
That was a bad idea.
Interesting jjajjangyun facts!
Jjajjangmyun is kinda like the bachelor food of Korea
So if you’re a dude and you’re living by yourself
You will probably be ordering jjajjangmyun a lot
This is the equivalent of macaroni and cheese for college students
So you know the whole culture of like
Valentine’s Day and then White Day
We did a couple of videos before
But the month after white day,
There’s black day.
For single people!
Who don’t have any special person to love.
And what they usually do on black day
Is eat jjajjangmyun.
People will get together
To eat jjajangmyun together, in sadness.
So there’s like a big group of people all single,
Eating it together.
With a big pile of tissues in the middle so they can all cry.
Or they can meet each other, and no
Longer be apart of Black Day.
Third interesting jjajjangmyun fact!
When people move into a new house,
They traditionally order jjajangmyun
I don’t know if that’s supposed to be
Something that’s supposed to be passed down in Korea,
Or if it’s just really easy to eat
And you don’t need anything much but a chopstick
But that seems to be a thing to do
And I’ve even seen it in the We Got Married dramas,
Where they move in and they eat jjajangmyun.
Fourth interesting fact!
This is supposed to be Chinese food!
Oh right!
But I’ve never actually had anything like this in Canada
For any of the Chinese food that I had
And any of the Chinese food that I had in Canada,
I can’t find here in Korea.
Listen! Toronto has an entire china town
Where Chinese people who only speak Chinese
Who make Chinese food, with Chinese restaurants,
It is legit Chinese food,
And this does not exist.
AND,
Our friend that lived in China said that,
This is not in china!
So Chinese food in Korea is really like,
Korean-fusion takes on Chinese food.
Chinese people who have come to Korean and had jjajjanmyun!
I want your opinion on this!
Can you get this meal in china or not?
And you can’t even answer that because
You’re in china and you can’t watch YouTube.
NA Nan a nan a nan a. You can’t watch the You Tubes!
This is not very good date food by the way you guys.
Unless your idea of a date is
Getting covered in grease
And not getting any napkins.
Korean deliveries provide everything for you,
Except for napkins.
Um, why didn’t you get me a napkin?
I didn’t know that you needed any
Look at me!
Oh! Sick! AH GAHD! Gross!
So that’s it for this week’s
Food adventure program for awesome people
I am unnaturally stuffed and I am going to go take
A four-hour nap.
I barely ate any of mine because
I’m not a piggy!
I’m going to sleep.
Simon, is a due-ji (piggy)
Hey Leigh, do you hear me?
Do you want some food Leigh?
Do you want some of my jjajjangmyun or …
Oh…..
Do you want some of mine?
Do you want some of this?
Do you want the last gun-mandu?
What if I eat it?
What if I eat all of it?
Ok.
These are the best part about ordering delivery in Korea.
You don’t have to clean anything up, you just dump it
All in the bag that they provide for you
And you leave it on the stairwell.
Pretty cool right?
Finished! Freedom.
